update.description:
# Segway Modular API Updates

## Introduction of Steps

This introduces a new API which divides the three Segway tasks, train, identify, and posterior, into steps allowing us to stop the processes at defined intervals to view and potentially modify the input files generated by Segway before and during training. The steps that have been defined are:

* init: Generates all input files, but does not submit any jobs to GMTK \(besides triangulate\). At the end of this step the input.master, segway.str, auxillary files, tri files, and the window.bed will all be generated.
* run: Submits jobs to GMTK. Produces params and viterbi files.
* finish: Selects the best training and identify instances and uses these to generate the output files.
* train-run-round: This step is specific to training. It will run a single round of training and then stop, allowing a user to view results and modify files.

## User Interface Changes

Users wishing to run all steps of a task together may continue to do so the same way they do now, writing segway <task>. 

To run a single step, use the command segway <task>-<step>. For example, segway identify-run will run the identify associated programs. 

A change to all users will be the order of the positional arguments and additional arguments provided to segway. Now users will only be able to specify arguments specific to each task, rather than having a downstream error occur. This means that the commands must now follow the order:

`"segway [GLOBAL_OPTION] TASK [TASK_OPTION] GENOMEDATA [GENOMEDATA ...] TRAINDIR [IDENTIFYDIR]"`

Where global options are those that apply to all tasks such as cluster arguments. Task options are those that are specific to the desired task.
update.title: Split Segway Tasks into Steps

content.raw: These refer to the details.sh and run.sh files in the log directory, not the individual files in the cmdline directory. These need to be appended since every time a new step is run, it adds new commands to each line. Perhaps the names are misleading and should be changed?

content.raw: Why are these appended now? Each cmdline file should be unique since it’s the command being run.
content.html: Why are these appended now? Each cmdline file should be unique since it’s the command being run.

content.raw: I think this is fine as long clobber actually removes all the intermediates as well. So if I had a training run along in any progression, if I run `train init --clobber` it will remove _everything_ and re-initialize. @hoffman might have some useful feedback regarding this option and the split steps.
content.html: I think this is fine as long clobber actually removes all the intermediates as well. So if I had a training run along in any progression, if I run train init --clobber it will remove everything and re-initialize. @hoffman might have some useful feedback regarding this option and the split steps.

content.raw: Reviewing clobber, all the files and directories it attempts to overwrite seem to be specific to the init step. All files from run and finish are overwritten regardless of whether or not they exist. As such, I would recommend moving the option to the init step specifically, rather than having it global as it is now. Is this alright?
content.html: Reviewing clobber, all the files and directories it attempts to overwrite seem to be specific to the init step. All files from run and finish are overwritten regardless of whether or not they exist. As such, I would recommend moving the option to the init step specifically, rather than having it global as it is now. Is this alright?

content.raw: I understand maximize log likelihood, but what is the "min by info\_criterion"? `info_criterion` is nowhere to be seen in this context.
content.html: I understand maximize log likelihood, but what is the "min by info_criterion"? info_criterion is nowhere to be seen in this context.

content.raw:
The results folders will contain tab files for each instance. These will store everything previously passed to finish through the instance\_params variable. This means that each one will store the best log likelihood \(or the best validation log likelihood if that was selected\), as well as the params file that goes with it. Lastly, it contains the various filenames used to generate the results: the input master and validation files. If we want to get rid of this folder, these could certainly be determined from the other files in the traindir, I just thought this was simpler for loading and reading between run and finish if you were interested in the results of the various instances.

‌

I have updated the docstring for TrainResults to better reflect what this file actually does, since it is just that class written out.
content.html:
The results folders will contain tab files for each instance. These will store everything previously passed to finish through the instance_params variable. This means that each one will store the best log likelihood (or the best validation log likelihood if that was selected), as well as the params file that goes with it. Lastly, it contains the various filenames used to generate the results: the input master and validation files. If we want to get rid of this folder, these could certainly be determined from the other files in the traindir, I just thought this was simpler for loading and reading between run and finish if you were interested in the results of the various instances.

‌

I have updated the docstring for TrainResults to better reflect what this file actually does, since it is just that class written out.

content.raw: Argparse will return an object containing values for all the options which apply to that task, setting them to none if there is nothing specified in the cmdline. The issue here is that observations does not apply to identify and so when we run segway identify at this point the options.observation object will not exist since that wasn’t a valid option for this task.
content.html: Argparse will return an object containing values for all the options which apply to that task, setting them to none if there is nothing specified in the cmdline. The issue here is that observations does not apply to identify and so when we run segway identify at this point the options.observation object will not exist since that wasn’t a valid option for this task.
